Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: disagree and no-disagree. Classify the comment as disagree if it expresses strong disagreement.

Positive Examples.input:
Comment: A whole boring column to connect Leitch to a white supremacist.

Leah,
Leave political commentary to the pundits , I am sure there is something trendy you can write about.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment expresses the writer's strong disagreement with the post that it replies to.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: See, O.L. Of Fatima really did convert the Russians!
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment does not express any sign of disagreement.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: I have no love for the Chiefs, but it was wonderful seeing Brady on his ass.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment does not show clear agreement or disagreement, and thus should be classified as no-disagree.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: Not a smart President. Sad.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment shows disagreement with the president.

Comment: This is oh so tiresome. First, no one cares about what Trudeau said about Castro, outside of a few rabid conservatives and the various leadership candidates of the CPC who think they can appeal to that rabid base. The really interesting question here is why these people are so lost in the past that they are fighting and evoking tropes from the Cold War. Don't they know that is over? Second, discussing Castro outside of the historical context is ludicrous. Castro is controversial precisely because he did  a lot of good along with the bad. As far as Latin American dictators go, Castro was one of the better ones  - a man who really did improve life for the great majority of his country's citizens, even as he resisted brutal American oppression. Through the 1960-1980s, Cuba was one of the best places in the region to live - much better than the American-backed vicious right wing dictatorships that slaughtered  their own people. That is what the rest of the world -and Trudeau -remembers.

Comment: No, we looked ridiculous to the rest of the world when countries like Australia successfully negotiated with the US for the return of their citizens held in Guantanamo, but we did NOTHING while one of our people - technically a child at capture - was subjected to the UN definition of torture out of the reach of US courts.

What we look like now is a nation of laws that manned-up and admitted a grievous error we did to one of our own (as we also did to Maher Arar). Better late than never.  We are finally reaffirming that Canadian citizenship really does mean something, even in foreign torture cells.

Comment: This editorial reeks of pure ignorance of history and context.  Cuba was one of the most unequal societies in the Americas when Castro came to power. It was a criminal regime, being fleeced by other criminals, often to the advantage of American gangsters. During Castro's time in power, particularly during the 1960s to 1990s, Cuba was a far better place to live than almost anywhere else in Central America. Places like El Salvador, Nicaragua, and Guatemala were in the middle of vicious civll wars and genocides, driven by American-backed forces. 80,000 people were killed in ES; 80,000 in two wars in Nicaragua; in Guatemala, a genocide against the native population killed more than 200,000. Castro was certainly a dictator and he certainly did things wrong; but he cannot compare to the far worse monsters around him. Fighting the Cold War decades after it is over -and during the failure of capitalism - is ludicrous. I suggest that the Globe editorial writers think more before they write.

Comment: I think in all fairness that before the Liberals end omnibus bills for good, they should have the opportunity to try one out for their political advantage. They have a lot of ground to make up after the disastrous Harper years, and Conservative complaints are falling on my deaf ears.

I do hope all the parties learn a lesson from this. If you don't want omnibus bills, don't present omnibus bills. If Trudeau did not present one here, the Conservatives would have no idea how horrible they are when you are in opposition. 

Clearly I like this government, and I'm willing to pardon their many apparent inconsistencies, up to a point. They are a long way from that, so I'll heave a contented sigh amidst the wailing and moaning from past champions of omnibus bills.

Comment: Gee, Denise, please do some research: the top climate scientist at MIT over the last half century, now retired, is Prof. Richard Lindzen, an American atmospheric physicist known for his work in the dynamics of the middle atmosphere, atmospheric tides, and ozone photochemistry. He  published more than 200 scientific papers and books. He was a key participant in the UN climate project until  his doubts overcame him.

 And as Lindzen says about various claims that one recent year was the "hottest ever" :  

“All that matters is that for almost 40 years, model projections have almost all exceeded observations.  Even if all the observed warming were due to greenhouse emissions, it would still point to low sensitivity. [.....] When someone says this is the warmest temperature on record, what are they talking about? It’s just nonsense. This is a very tiny change period.”

Comment: A few things to note here:

First – weed today is not stronger than it was “back in the day”. That’s a myth and should have been caught by the editor before this garbage column was published. 

Second – the molecules that make up the smell of weed smoke are non-polar. This means they will only dissolve in oil and not water. That is why weed smoke – while you may not like the smell – is not very “sticky”. It goes away after awhile and doesn’t infest your clothes (unless you haven’t washed them in awhile in which case they will have a lot of body oil in them). The molecules that make tobacco smoke smell are polar molecules. This means they will dissolve in water. That is why being around someone who is smoking tobacco can make your clothes smell terrible later on and why tobacco smoke is so “sticky”. 

Third – weed doesn’t remove ambition. At least, it hasn’t removed mine. If anything it allows me to relax and decompress after a long week at work.

Worst. Eddie. Column. Ever.

Comment: Hate to break it to you, but Canada is not and never has been a democracy.

It is a top-down English colonial system some would call a "pseudocracy", whose main goal was to muzzle settlers who were prone to thinking they had been sold a bill of goods,-- as in the rebellions of the Upper and Lower Canadas in 1837.

The word "democracy" and its cognates appears nowhere in the original Confederation Act of 1867. It appears three times in the so-called Constitution Act of 1982, twice as captions and once in graciously conferring the right to vote,-- a right shared with such egregious regimes as North Korea. The 1982 Act is a sham never ratified by Québec, cosily and paternalistically formulated by Pierre Trudeau and the remaining Premiers over the heads of Canadians.

The only threat to this canard is that Canadians will look covetously at the success of another system, and want to jettison it and the corrupt sinecurists holding them to ransom.

Hence the unease over Donald Trump.

Comment: Mr. Gibson really should get some legal advice before he sticks his neck out and makes a fool of himself.

Section 92(10(a) empowers a province to legislate over various local works and undertakings:

            "(a) Lines of Steam or other Ships, Railways, Roads, Telegraphs, and other Works and Undertakings         connecting the Province with any other or others of the Provinces, or extending beyond the Limits of the Province

Pipelines are not mentioned.      

The federal Parliament  can, however, declare a work to be for the general benefit of Canada or three or more provinces under section 92(10(c):

           "(c) Such Works as, although wholly situate within the Province, are before or after their Execution declared by the Parliament of Canada to be for the general Advantage of Canada or for the Advantage of Three or more of the Provinces.

In the absence of a federal declaration, B.C. is within its rights to lay down condition for the expansion of this pipeline.

Comment: You don’t like the amount of money?  

Blame the Harper government.

Before you curse me, read this….

Khadr filed his suit for damages in 2004, asking for a modest amount of damages. Did we seek his repatriation (as every other Western country did), and try to negotiate a settlement to the law suit then? 

No.

Instead, we fought it – big time.  

There were 30 separate court decisions during the 9 Harper years – all (or almost all?) of which we lost.  How much did those losses cost?  I found out the cost of two (2) of them so far, from Hansard: the 2008 and 2010 Supreme Court cases -  slightly over $625,000.  I wonder what the other 28 cost.  

After the 2010 SCC decision confirming that our government had seriously violated his Charter rights, Khadr’s team amended the  damage claim, way up – because they had more evidence and the biggest issue in the case was then proven.  Did we try to negotiate a settlement then?  

No. The Harper government fought him for another 20 decisions.

Comment: "Logging will transfer vast amounts of carbon from the forest to the atmosphere ..."  Not necessarily. When you cut down a tree, you eliminate it's ability to store carbon in the future, but the products made from those trees still store that carbon ... it's locked up in the wood product. A tree that falls and rots stores some carbon in the soil, but most is released to the atmosphere. When trees operate in a system, forests are great carbon sinks, no doubt, but I think you're overestimating the value of a small patch of trees here that are not part of a larger forest system ... trees that are apparently getting knocked down by storms and probably rotting, based on other comments here. You'll get nearly as much carbon storage cutting and replanting as you will leaving them to rot in such a small clump.

Comment: The Legislature fiddles while the state burns.

A shutdown would not only cost the state millions of dollars in economic and investment damage, but even laying off every state worker would end up costing the state millions of dollars. Because state workers are laid-off, not furloughed like federal employees in shutdown, the state is legally required to cash-out the employee leave banks of every single employee effected. You can safely assume hundreds of thousands of hours of leave would have to be written off the books with checks, and long-service employees who have climbed the payscale will get large payouts (a quarter million or more for some folks I know who have several thousand hours in the bank).

The brinksmanship is a bad joke. It doesn't get anything accomplished other than making our state government look as dysfunctional as the federal government. The Legislature needs to do its damned job.

Comment: I've paddled in the Ala Wai since I was a kid,  It's gotten progressively worse in terms of pollution, run off and homeless trash that flows down into the ocean where many of us surf Bowls.  When the sewage spill occurred the entire ocean out past the 2nd channel buoy stunk and the water was green/brown.  What is being talked about is needed, but in addition, the flow of water was supposed to have an inlet/outlet at the Kapahulu groin so that the canal would actually have movement with the tides.  However, because Waikiki is the tourist mecca that it is, it's doubtful this connection would ever happen as it would probably make the Kapahulu end more like the Ala Moana end.  Run off from the mountains is inevitable.  Silt, mud and debris need to be dredged regularly to keep the canal deep enough particularly where Manoa stream empties into it.  If there is a need for a TAT tax increase, this would be it.  Hotels won't complain when it benefits themselves.

Comment: Comment 4
One more note.  On the positive side.   Kaczynski is trying to find a place where a line can be drawn, some way to put some definitions around what is and is not permissible.  I just do not know if it can be done by limiting decisions couples need to make regarding a child who is “very deformed” – I think that is a parental decision.  But, we need to put some definitions around abortion; it  should not be a normal form of birth control.  Most European countries put some limits on when an abortion is no longer a choice – most at 12, some 16 weeks, up to 20 weeks – I am open to correction.  In the U.S. we have been drawing these lines in state legislatures and finding some acceptance of restrictions starting at (I think) 20 weeks.  We need to deal with abortions afterward that protect the life of a woman and abortions in case of fetal abnormality.  We need to think about how to make some sense of BOTH the rights of child and the rights of a woman.  The Hyde Amndmnt needs to go.

Comment: I hate to say it but she is bang on.  In a system so reliant on the provisions of the Charter, how could the judiciary not rely on proof beyond a reasonable doubt.  How can there be a presumption of guilt for an accused.  What gets lost in all of this debate is the shear complexity involving the law of consent.  It is easy to convict someone for Assault or Theft.  There is only one step to this process.  If the sexual act was the only element to prove, then of course the statistics would be higher.  Not only does the Crown have to prove the sex per se, but they also have to show that it was without consent.  This is so very difficult.  Further lost in the debate, is an accused willingness to fight such a charge.  No person - hardened criminal or regular joe - wants the tag of being a sex offender.  This is why most are so grossly contested in our courts.  The whole argument as it pertains to the low conviction rate has many different areas of consideration.  It is not that simple.

Comment: Clearly the State Land Board, Gov. Brown included, intended to sell the Elliott after selling the first 1500 acre chunk to Seneca. The K12 PERS fund will probably be a winner in this sale. Most Oregonians will, now and in the long run, be losers.

Comment: If you want top-quality education, top-quality roads, then that costs upfront. Yes, it pays off in the long run, but it means having a tax increase in the short term. Everyone wants top quality services, but nobody wants to invest in them.

When's the last time you lobbied your councillor to increase your municipal tax in order to spend a little more on better quality paving? It exists - look at many European countries with similar freeze-thaw cycles to ours. Their roads are in much better shape!

When's the last time you lobbied your MPP to increase your taxes to pay for better quality education?

We can have better things, but the idea that "innefficient bureaucracies" are the reason we don't have them is false. Yes, I agree their is government waste, but there will always be, and eliminating that isn't nearly enough to pay for what we want.

Comment: Hurricane, I disagree with your disagreement.  I am using history to support my view.  When World War II ended, the U.S. and its allies were looking for anything and everything the Japanese might have done that could be considered a war crime.  Forcing women to be sex slaves certainly should have met the standard for a war crime.  With tens of thousands of Korean and Chinese women reportedly being forced to be sex slaves, you would think that at least one of them would have come forward to make the allegation immediately after the war, yet none did.   It was not until the 1992, about 47 years after the war ended, that a researcher reported about the Japanese military operating brothels for its soldiers staffed with “comfort women” or “sex slaves” from the occupied territories.   I am a bit skeptical about claims made 47 years after they allegedly occurred.

Comment: Government and  media must start to do a much better job covering this topic.  Terms are being mixed up and this is all misleading.  Gender does not, and cannot appear on a birth certificate.  Sex does.  Sex is biologic / genetic and while traditionally has been considered binary M/F, is genetically confined to XX, XY, XXY or X.  The sex assigned at birth is most often based on visible genetalia, which can sometimes be ambiguous or misleading, and can only be truly confirmed through a genetic test.  Gender is the self-perception that is formed by a person to identify as male, female or somewhere in-between; it is on a continuum and is not necessarily static. A new-born can't really be deemed to have a gender since they don't yet have any perception of male or female.  Since gender is on a continuum and can change, there is no point in having gender on identity documents in the first place.  If we are to retain sex on ID, it should be based on the actual chromosomes not a visual check.

Comment: Equating high airport fees with high ticket prices is utter nonsense. 

Air Canada is banking record profits on the back of continuing low fuel prices. Yet has anyone seen air fares decrease by even $1?  No.  Yet Air Canada has the audacity to continue charging "fuel surcharges" over  and above their base fares. 

Air Canada replaced mainline service on dozens of routes with Rouge service, their "low cost airline." Has anyone seen air fares on those routes decrease by even $1?  No.  They remain the same as what Air Canada charged for mainline service. Rouge is "low cost" only to Air Canada, which pays crews half what it pays its mainline employees and banks the rest.

In its annual report, Air Canada admits airport fees represent just 6.5% of its operating costs.

Comment: Callwaiting - In reading your responses here, I believe you are not just rhetorically repeating lines in a pet argument and so I want to respond. My experience is the same as many others here, which is that gay couples and gay parents remain and will remain a statistical minority (by far). There are places in the country where those families are more common because, like most families, gay families choose when they are able to live where they are welcome, safe and where the culture includes them and their children. So it can seem in certain parts of the country that, everywhere you look, you see gay families which means you see "fewer" straight families. But it just isn't the overall statistical truth. Additionally, gay parents mostly raise straight children because straight (heterosexual) is the statistical norm and so "gay parents" are, in most families, a one generation phenomenon and then that family goes back to the statistically normal pattern: straights parents, straight kids.

Repeated calls to employers, neighbors, friends, relatives.  The tone of voice, language used by collectors were over the top.  In 1977, in response to the demands of consumers, the Congress passed the law.  The issue I am addressing is the collector of the debt, not the debt itself.  I am saying that it does not matter if the debt is sold five times, if the collector is abusive, then the law has been violated.  What the Court is doing here is given shelter and comfort to businesses buying debt instruments, thus avoiding the intent of the law itself.  Get it?  Got it?  Good.

Comment: I agree that the U.S. role in the world isn't about friendship and never has been. It's purely about self-interest, and it's in not in our interests to extricate ourselves from relationships and alliances in which we have major influence. Yes, we pay more than our fair share to maintain these relationships, but that's what happens when you're the big dog.

The nations of the world are not a "community" in any serious sense. But, like it or not, they are more interdependent today than ever before in human history. That interdependence is only going to increase, with or without the U.S., and it would be the height of folly for us to surrender our influence as that happens.

Comment: Frankly, as far as I'm concerned, much of Houston is now a Superfund site. The contaminant chickens have already fled the coop from many industrial/chemical sites like these in Houston. The people who live there, like the people who live in the fumes of that refinery near Denver, have an overly-optimistic view of their body's natural resistance to toxic chemical contamination. I expect they believe it's all sufficiently regulated and contained, and there exist safeguards informed by the most current objective science and these would never let the public be inadvertently exposed to anything harmful.

Pragmatically, in the world we face today, what a seemingly-foolish hope and what a sordid death wish. Sites like these can only be fled and, in the future, perhaps, prevented altogether. Still, looking at the way fracking has been allowed to pillage the environmental integrity of so much of the United States, it's hard to believe it wasn't always a fifth-column attack on our futures.

Comment: If you truly want equality as you claim, here's a suggestion: make your government honor the treaties. Educate yourself on what treaties are and what that means for Canada and all Canadians and First Nations.  Understand the fact that First Nations are first and foremost, treaty partners with the Crown. This makes "we" i.e. you a treaty partner as well.  The only reason you can live here today in this land of plenty is because these treaties were made.  They are living documents,the law of the land, the supreme law.  And these treaties carry with them promises and obligations. Treaties were made so that settlers could share the land with the First Nations and that is why some First Nations were assigned certain health and education benefits; it is your rent.  These obligations have never been truly fulfilled which is why you see extreme poverty, etc., on reserves. Your attempt to try and erase facts and history with this blanket "race-based rights" nonsense is ignorant and obvious.

Comment: Sorry, but where is the scientific evidence, data, that sea lions eat land mammals such as humans on docks and beaches?

Look, I make no excuses for people who get too close to wild animals or who foolishly feed them bread or whatever.

But in looking at the video, I do not see evidence of this being a moment of "you human are my lunch". Yes, the sea lion grabbed her flapping white shirt tail while she was hunched way over away from the sea, but from that odd angle she might well have looked like a big Gucci bag or a picnic basket or a container of some sort. Animals from seagulls to raccoons to rats to crows to monkeys will make a quick grab for a container or bag if they think it might contain food, but that does not mean they eat people.

Sea lions do not hesitate to instantly chomp and tear up the food that is in their diet in the sea, and yet that did not happen to the girl.

I agree with all of the advice and suggestions, to stay away. But that animal's intention was unclear.
